3 Power Over

CoaXPress

The microEnable 5 CoaXPress Series frame grabbers support Power-over-CoaXPress cameras, as Power-over-CoaXPress (PoCXP) in general is a mandatory feature of the CoaXPress standard.

The microEnable 5 CoaXPress Series frame grabbers have a connector at the rear end that has necessarily to be connected to power the frame grabber and to provide PoCXP at the BNC connectors. This connector can be connected to a standard 4pin power connector of a PC power supply.

Camera Link

All microEnable 5 Camera Link Series frame grabbers support power-over Camera Link cameras.

5 Pin Configuration Trigger

CoaXPress

1 Trigger Output 0 Port A +3.3V 2
3 Trigger Output 1 Port A +3.3V 4
5 Trigger Output 2 Port A GND 6
7 Trigger Output 3 Port A GND 8
9 Trigger Input 0 Port A GND 10
11 Trigger Input 1 Port A GND 12
13 Trigger Input 2 Port A GND 14
15 Trigger Input 3 Port A GND 16
17 Trigger Output 4 Port B
 GND 18
19

Trigger Output 5 Port B

 GND 20
21 Trigger Output 6 Port B
 GND 22
23 Trigger Output 7 Port B
 GND 24
25 Trigger Input 4 Port B GND 26
27 Trigger Input 5 Port B GND 28
29 Trigger Input 6 Port B GND 30
31 Trigger Input 7 Port B VCCIO (+3.3 V / +2.5 V) * 32
33 Presence Detect VCCIO (+3.3 V / +2.5 V) * 34

 Plug assignment of the trigger plug (34 pin flat cable).

* Voltage on pins 32 and 34: Frame grabber mE5 VQ8-CXP6B (with BNC connectors) has VCCIO = 3.3 V on pins 32 and 34. Frame grabber mE5 VQ8-CXP6D (with DIN connectors) has VCCIO = 2.5 V on pins 32 and 34, but can be switched to 3.3 V (assembly option).

Per default, signals are driven by open-collector drivers, but can be switched to push-pull by software. Pullups are on-board.

Please refer to the sections Opto Trigger for microEnable IV and TTL Trigger, respectively, to learn how trigger extension boards are connected and used. Please refer to the specific Applet documentation to learn how the trigger signals can be used.


Camera Link

The trigger pin configuration for microEnable Camera Link frame grabbers conforms to the Camera Link standard specification.

The voltage on VCCIO is 2.5 V , but can be switched to 3.3 V (assembly option).

Per default, signals are driven by open-collector drivers, but can be switched to push-pull by software. Pullups are on-board.

Please refer to the sections Opto Trigger for microEnable IV and TTL Trigger, respectively, to learn how trigger extension boards are connected and used. Please refer to the specific Applet documentation to learn how the trigger signals can be used.



6 LED Description

CoaXPress

LEDs on the Slot Bracket

There are four/five LEDs mounted on the slot bracket of the microEnable 5 CXP VQ8-CXP6D (CXP with DIN connectors) frame grabbers that indicate the state of the individual CXP links:

There are no LEDs on the slot bracket of the microEnable 5 VQ8-CXP6B (CXP with BNC connectors) frame grabbers.

On-Board LEDs

There are eight LEDs mounted on the mE5 CXP frame grabbers (BNC and DIN).Some LEDs have fixed functions, others are programmable (software/firmware).

Functions of the LEDs (from left to right):

1) FPGA Configuration DONE

If the "DONE" LED is on, the frame grabber is ready for operation:

  • The FPGA on the frame grabber has been configured successfully.
  • The frame grabber identifies itself as a PCIe board and is recognized by the PC.
  • Under Windows, it is detected by the Device Manager.

2) Applet Specific LED1

3) Applet Specific LED2

4) Applet Specific LED3

5) Applet Specific LED4

6) Power Good

7) 12V Power On

8) 12V Power for PoCXP On


Camera Link

LEDs on the Slot Bracket

There are no LEDs on the slot bracket of Camera Link frame grabbers. On Camera Link frame grabbers, the state of the individual Camera Link links is indicated via on-board LEDs (see below).

On-Board LEDs

There are six green LEDs mounted on the microEnable 5 Camera Link frame grabbers.The LEDs have fixed functions.

Three LEDs are dedicated to Port A and three to Port B:



The LEDs indicate the following:

Port A

Port B

PoCL on

PoCL test

PoCL off



7 Important Information Regarding PCIe Bus Data Through-Put

The PCIe bus data throughput depends on the motherboard, the chip set and the BIOS configuration of the PC and can differ from slot to slot. It can also depend on the number of installed PCIe-boards, e.g., a PCIe x8 connector may support only x4 performance.

Always check the mainboard manual thoroughly to be sure.
